message: I meant Campfire
I guess maybe you hit why though :p
It should be a great panel and it's definitely a hot topic, but I'm wondering what other folks want to know about in this type of panel
when is the panel?
@howardgr Friday at 5pm http://schedule.sxsw.com/events/event_IAP000531
Why is Propane so popular in the business world despite it's lack of features / improvement / any attention given to it at all by 37Signals
and IRC is fun but hard to learn
@rwwmike I don't think it's sudden at all
So, we're going to have Caleb from Yobongo, Steve from GroupMe, Lucy from Beluga and Leah from Convore
I mean, admittedly it didn't start getting really popular for the general populus until AOL added chat rooms, but that was like what? 13-15 years ago?
And of course, Leah, Caleb, Steve, Lucy - if you're in here and want to throw some ideas out there, please do. :)
God why did I say Propane
There's not really any integration at all
I'm wondering...why is this suddenly a hot topic? PR-created media frenzy? Critical mass in smartphones? Evolution in the form of core services?
@kneath Very much so. I grew up on BBSes. I've never really lived *without* group chat. Maybe it's the "sudden" explosion of mobile solutions...

Yobongo takes an interesting approach by focussing on physical proximity. I haven't used it (no iphone). Once novelty wears off, what will keep people interested? Focus on creating real life friendships?
Thanks Leah - I will add it to the schedule. Hope to see you there.
Howdy! Excited for the discussion. Happy to answer any questions people have.
@kneath I think Propane (the mac client for 37 signals Campfire) is so popular because there aren't many desktop apps for group chat that aren't IRC-based
Well, I guess those poor saps will miss out on a great conversation.
I'm curious what lessons Yobongo took from other location-based group chat services that came before, like Message Party.
Ahh campfire. I think campfire is popular because it's part of a whole suite of other useful things, no?
@rwwmike I blame MG
@leah CF does *some* things that make it very suitable for being an ad-hoc "organizational memory" for random stuff
@leah hehe.
@kneath although 37 signals is a strong brand
Group chat has been a core part of pretty much everyone I know in my generation
The past 4 years or so I've worked at companies who work in Propane pretty much 24/7 and we didn't use basecamp, highrise, etc
Friday at 5 pm a bunch of folks will be at the Apple Store in Austin buying ipads
Yobongo seems to have the lowest barrier to get in and start using it
Why isn't everyone just using Skype?

With all the competitors in this space, it appears the barriers to entry are low.  In the future, do you expect this high rate of new-entrants to continue, or will it get harder to start a new group-chat product as the current players mature?
How significant is BlackBerry as a platform for supporting group chat?  Are you able to be successful without it?   What do you think of the impending BBM release for iPhone and Android?
Do users who are outside of the techblog sphere realize there is so much group-chat competition?  That is, do most users have just one group chat client installed, or is there a lot of overlap?
Oh man, I was totally expecting trollage when you first joined here @TheDoctor with that name and no avatar, but those are great questions :) Hooray!
As a matter of opinion, who is in the lead for the mobile group-chat crown?
What are the future revenue drivers for the group-chat space?
and someone tell me what the answer was b/c I'm won't be there to see it :-)
@keath you bugger, I just read the backchat... Propane lack of features/improvement/attention? Wat?
What happened to kik?
haha

Okay, question for panelists: It's likely that group-chat products (like project management products) are designed around "this is how *I* want to communicate". How much do you listen to your customers as far as feature suggestions go - especially features you don't have a personal burning need for?

Given that the US was one of the last countries to adopt SMS, and has a different payment model (both sender and recipient pays) does a winning US strategy for mobile group chat reproduce well for the rest of the world?  Anyone tried it yet?
WhatsApp, KakaoTalk and PingChat all have mobile group-chat, but have been largely ignored in discussion of the 'group-chat bloodbath'    What separates the winners on the panel from these losers?
oh yeah, add BrightKite to the group-messaging list
@ericflo Heh, I agree - @TheDoctor - great questions.
@TheDoctor I didn't actually create the line-up, though I would posit that it's a matter of connections, in the long run. Isn't it all? It's all about who you know, right?
@leah - is there a view where I can see all the things I've starred?
Do you think we'll see other LBS check-in like services add group chat to their mobile apps via APIs or build their own? Example (groupme + foursquare mashup)
@protocool if a feature suggestion is a good one, we've probably heard it a lot :)

@protocool in response to your question about customer feedback - at Convore we do listen to all feedback and take note. However, we don't implement everything right away. We wait until we start hearing the same idea lots of times.
@protocool I should probably be saving my response for the panel!
oops

Is there a feeling that you must have an app? With todays phones will browser based be fine? I know it will lack the push notifications but it seems like my phone is giving me some notification every 5 mins anyway....<sigh>
Where do you see monetization for for group chat coming from?

@leah I "take note" too but I might be a bit tyrannical in that if it isn't something I personally see the value in, I'm unlikely to implement it, no matter how popular. It's not just that I'm the most important user, it's also because if I don't really care about the feature then I probably won't do a stellar job of it. So I guess I'm wondering how closely people stick to a "core vision" - and whether that might account for all the different flavours of group-chat: the "right" way to handle group-chat is a very personal opinion.
(otherwise we'd all be hooking into IRC servers)
Good luck to everyone tomorrow.  I hope I can read a transcript or account of the panel, since I won't be in Austin.
